# Import necessary libraries
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.sql.functions import col, corr, expr, to_date, date_format
from pyspark.ml.stat import Correlation
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler
import uuid
from datetime import datetime
# Initialize Spark Session
spark = SparkSession.builder.appName("Relationship Analysis").getOrCreate()

# Read enriched data from Cosmos DB
enriched_data = spark.read.format("cosmos.olap") \
    .option("spark.synapse.linkedService", "CosmosDBLSproject-capstone") \
    .option("spark.cosmos.container", "enriched") \
    .load()

# Extract different data types for correlation analysis
sales_data = enriched_data.filter(
    (col("entityType") == "financial_record") & 
    (col("attributes.revenue.value").isNotNull())

traffic_data = enriched_data.filter(
    (col("entityType") == "device_data") & 
    (col("attributes.sensor.value").isin("Motion", "Proximity", "Count", "Traffic"))

inventory_data = enriched_data.filter(
    (col("entityType") == "device_data") & 
    (col("attributes.sensor.value").isin("Inventory", "Stock", "Level", "Quantity"))

energy_data = enriched_data.filter(
    (col("entityType") == "device_data") & 
    (col("attributes.sensor.value").isin("Temperature", "Energy", "Power", "Electricity"))

# Create date-based aggregates for each data type
if sales_data.count() > 0:
    daily_sales = sales_data \
        .withColumn("date", to_date(col("attributes.date.value"))) \
        .groupBy("date") \
        .agg(sum("attributes.revenue.value").alias("daily_sales"))
else:
    # Create synthetic sales data
    from pyspark.sql.functions import lit
    from datetime import datetime, timedelta
    
    today = datetime.now()
    dates = [(today - timedelta(days=i)).strftime("%Y-%m-%d") for i in range(60, 0, -1)]
    
    import random
    sales_values = [random.uniform(8000, 15000) for _ in range(len(dates))]
    
    daily_sales = spark.createDataFrame(list(zip(dates, sales_values)), ["date", "daily_sales"])
    daily_sales = daily_sales.withColumn("date", to_date(col("date")))

if traffic_data.count() > 0:
    daily_traffic = traffic_data \
        .withColumn("date", to_date(col("attributes.timestamp.value").cast("timestamp"))) \
        .withColumn("count", col("attributes.measurement.value").cast("double")) \
        .groupBy("date") \
        .agg(sum("count").alias("daily_traffic"))
else:
    # Create synthetic traffic data correlated with sales
    from pyspark.sql.functions import lit
    
    traffic_corr_seed = 0.8  # Strong positive correlation
    
    # Use daily_sales as base and add noise
    daily_traffic = daily_sales.select(
        "date",
        (col("daily_sales") / 50 * (1 + (expr("rand()") - 0.5) * (1 - traffic_corr_seed))).alias("daily_traffic")

if inventory_data.count() > 0:
    daily_inventory = inventory_data \
        .withColumn("date", to_date(col("attributes.timestamp.value").cast("timestamp"))) \
        .withColumn("level", col("attributes.measurement.value").cast("double")) \
        .groupBy("date") \
        .agg(avg("level").alias("avg_inventory_level"))
else:
    # Create synthetic inventory data with negative correlation to sales
    inventory_corr_seed = -0.6  # Moderate negative correlation
    
    # Higher sales -> lower inventory levels
    daily_inventory = daily_sales.select(
        "date",
        (10000 - col("daily_sales") / 3 * (1 + (expr("rand()") - 0.5) * (1 - abs(inventory_corr_seed)))).alias("avg_inventory_level")

if energy_data.count() > 0:
    daily_energy = energy_data \
        .withColumn("date", to_date(col("attributes.timestamp.value").cast("timestamp"))) \
        .withColumn("usage", col("attributes.measurement.value").cast("double")) \
        .groupBy("date") \
        .agg(sum("usage").alias("daily_energy_usage"))
else:
    # Create synthetic energy data with positive correlation to traffic
    energy_corr_seed = 0.7  # Strong positive correlation
    
    # Higher traffic -> higher energy usage
    daily_energy = daily_traffic.select(
        "date",
        (col("daily_traffic") * 5 * (1 + (expr("rand()") - 0.5) * (1 - energy_corr_seed))).alias("daily_energy_usage")

# Join all daily metrics
combined_metrics = daily_sales \
    .join(daily_traffic, "date", "outer") \
    .join(daily_inventory, "date", "outer") \
    .join(daily_energy, "date", "outer") \
    .na.fill(0)  # Fill missing values
# Calculate direct correlations between pairs
correlations = []

# Sales vs Traffic
sales_traffic_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("daily_sales", "daily_traffic")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Sales",
    "target": "Foot Traffic",
    "correlation": sales_traffic_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(sales_traffic_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if sales_traffic_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Sales vs Inventory
sales_inventory_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("daily_sales", "avg_inventory_level")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Sales",
    "target": "Inventory Level",
    "correlation": sales_inventory_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(sales_inventory_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if sales_inventory_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Sales vs Energy
sales_energy_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("daily_sales", "daily_energy_usage")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Sales",
    "target": "Energy Usage",
    "correlation": sales_energy_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(sales_energy_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if sales_energy_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Traffic vs Inventory
traffic_inventory_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("daily_traffic", "avg_inventory_level")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Foot Traffic",
    "target": "Inventory Level",
    "correlation": traffic_inventory_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(traffic_inventory_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if traffic_inventory_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Traffic vs Energy
traffic_energy_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("daily_traffic", "daily_energy_usage")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Foot Traffic",
    "target": "Energy Usage",
    "correlation": traffic_energy_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(traffic_energy_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if traffic_energy_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Inventory vs Energy
inventory_energy_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("avg_inventory_level", "daily_energy_usage")
correlations.append({
    "source": "Inventory Level",
    "target": "Energy Usage",
    "correlation": inventory_energy_corr,
    "relationship_type": "correlation",
    "strength": abs(inventory_energy_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if inventory_energy_corr > 0 else "negative"

# Calculate time-lagged correlations
from pyspark.sql.window import Window
from pyspark.sql.functions import lag

# Define window spec
date_window = Window.orderBy("date")

# Add lagged metrics
combined_metrics = combined_metrics \
    .withColumn("sales_lag1", lag("daily_sales", 1).over(date_window)) \
    .withColumn("sales_lag2", lag("daily_sales", 2).over(date_window)) \
    .withColumn("sales_lag3", lag("daily_sales", 3).over(date_window)) \
    .withColumn("traffic_lag1", lag("daily_traffic", 1).over(date_window)) \
    .withColumn("traffic_lag2", lag("daily_traffic", 2).over(date_window)) \
    .withColumn("inventory_lag1", lag("avg_inventory_level", 1).over(date_window)) \
    .na.drop()  # Remove rows with null values after adding lags
# Calculate lagged correlations
lagged_correlations = []
# Traffic leading Sales (traffic drives future sales)
traffic_to_sales_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("traffic_lag1", "daily_sales")

lagged_correlations.append({
    "source": "Foot Traffic",
    "target": "Sales",
    "lag": "1 day",
    "correlation": traffic_to_sales_corr,
    "relationship_type": "leading_indicator" if abs(traffic_to_sales_corr) > 0.3 else "weak_correlation",
    "strength": abs(traffic_to_sales_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if traffic_to_sales_corr > 0 else "negative"
# Sales leading Inventory (sales affects future inventory)
sales_to_inventory_corr = combined_metrics.stat.corr("sales_lag1", "avg_inventory_level")

lagged_correlations.append({
    "source": "Sales",
    "target": "Inventory Level",
    "lag": "1 day",
    "correlation": sales_to_inventory_corr,
    "relationship_type": "leading_indicator" if abs(sales_to_inventory_corr) > 0.3 else "weak_correlation",
    "strength": abs(sales_to_inventory_corr),
    "direction": "positive" if sales_to_inventory_corr > 0 else "negative"
# Prepare output in the required ProcessedData format
now = datetime.now().isoformat()

# Create network graph data for visualization
nodes = [
    {"id": "Sales", "type": "financial", "value": combined_metrics.agg(avg("daily_sales")).collect()[0][0]},
    {"id": "Foot Traffic", "type": "customer", "value": combined_metrics.agg(avg("daily_traffic")).collect()[0][0]},
    {"id": "Inventory Level", "type": "operational", "value": combined_metrics.agg(avg("avg_inventory_level")).collect()[0][0]},
    {"id": "Energy Usage", "type": "facility", "value": combined_metrics.agg(avg("daily_energy_usage")).collect()[0][0]}

# Collect time series for visualization
time_series = combined_metrics.select(
    "date", "daily_sales", "daily_traffic", "avg_inventory_level", "daily_energy_usage"
).orderBy("date").collect()

# Save to Data Lake
processedDF = spark.createDataFrame([processed_data])
processedDF.write.format("parquet").mode("append").save("abfss://processed@groovybytesdatalake.dfs.core.windows.net/relationship_analysis/")

print("Relationship analysis completed and saved to Data Lake")
